item.description:
The Singing Revolution Estonia / USA 2007 94 minutes

I had the pleasure of seeing this on a trip back to NYC last year. The Singing Revolution depicts this little known detail of 20th century history as it represents what is best about the human spirit in response to tolitarian rule.

Most people don't think about singing when they think about revolutions. But song was the weapon of choice when, between 1987 and 1991, Estonians sought to free themselves from decades of brutal Soviet occupation. During those years, hundreds of thousands gathered in public to sing forbidden patriotic songs and to rally for independence. James Tusty and Maureen Castle Tusty's feature documentary tells the moving story of how the Estonian people peacefully regained their freedom?and helped topple an empire along the way. Kendall description

The thrill of this documentary is in the remarkable story of the Little Country That Could. Film.com

As far as the plot goes, widespread lack of familiarity with Estonia's recent history actually works in the film's favor: Suspense born of ignorance lends the unfolding drama the urgency of a political thriller. Chicago Tribune

Here's a link to a complete review: http://seattlepi.nwso...

Hope to see you there,
Tom
item.how_to_find_us: Tom will be holding up a meetup sign at the film's conclusion and then its off to a local restaurant for our group discussion
item.why: It's a powerful story of a nation that, almost literally, sang its way to freedom.
item.name: Estonia's "The Singing Revolution"
